sentence.text: Patient 1 (Fig. 2A) is an 18-year-old woman from Pakistan who was born with a bilateral cleft lip and palate deformity and a less severe form of the deformity in relationship to her younger sister.
The bilateral cleft lip and palate was repaired before she was 1 year old, and she received an alveolar bone graft at the age of 12.5 years.
She is hyperteloric and has narrow palpebral fissures, epicanthal folds, and high arched and flared eyebrows.
She wears glasses and is near sighted.
She has a scarred prolabial segment with a tightly adherent upper lip and a central notch of the upper lip.
There is a residual stepoff with a wide philtrum.
She also has a mild beaking deformity of her nose but is otherwise fairly symmetric.
She has had revision performed of the nasal deformity whereby the columella was lengthened.
Her maxillary arch is collapsed, and a crossbite is present.
She has braces in place for dental crowding.
Her palate is now repaired and rises symmetrically in the midline, and she has excellent speech.
The patient is in the 12th grade in general education and earns A grades.
She has passed the state high school exit exam and plans to attend college.
